Legal_Issue: Right to a fair hearing, right to an interpreter
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Evidence_Assessment: Post-hearing analysis revealed significant interpretation errors affecting testimony
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court allowed the judicial review
Credibility_Factor: Adverse credibility findings due to poor interpretation
Legal_Rule: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms guarantees the right to an interpreter
Procedural_Issue: Lack of continuous, precise, competent, impartial, and contemporaneous interpretation
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of procedural fairness due to inadequate interpretation
Outcome_on_Merits: Case remanded for redetermination with proper interpretation
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Applicants' rights were infringed due to poor-quality interpretation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Discrepancies in interpretation during hearing, post-hearing analysis of errors
Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Section 14
Applicant_Challenge: Denied right to effective interpretation affecting fair hearing
Legal_Rule_Source: Constitutional law – Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Legal_Provision: Section 14, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 14, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Outcome_of_Review: Successful – applicants’ rights found to be violated
Governing_Rule: Section 14 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
